key_points: Egyptian authorities may seek over $1 billion in compensation for clearing the Ever Given from the Suez Canal.
Osama Rabie, chairman of the Suez Canal Authority, cited losses in canal revenue, equipment costs, and manpower as reasons for the high compensation figure.
The Ever Given, a 200,000 ton mega-container carrier, was refloated six days after becoming stuck, causing a major disruption in international shipping.
The incident held up $9 billion in global trade per day and left 422 vessels waiting to pass through the Suez Canal.
Rabie hopes for a compensation agreement soon but did not specify who might be liable to pay.
First-hand accounts from rescue workers highlighted the dangers and challenges faced in freeing the ship.
An investigation into the incident is underway, examining potential human and technical errors.
The complex ownership and management structure of the Ever Given adds to the challenge of determining responsibility.
Insurance industry losses are estimated to be in the low hundreds of millions of dollars, according to Brian Schneider of Fitch Ratings.
The ship's operator, Bernhard Schulte Shipmanagement, and owner, Shoei Kisen, are in discussions about compensation but have not provided specifics.
spokespersons: Osama Rabie (Chairman and Managing Director, Suez Canal Authority)
Brian Schneider (Senior Director, Insurance division of Fitch Ratings)
